posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>Here we close our commentaries on the historical books of the Old Testament. >2. There is a discrepancy here: the fact that the apostles taught things by word of mouth does not mean that anything that you believe today, which has no scriptural support, was therefore taught by the Apostles. This would need to be demonstrated.

The final authority, established by Christ, is the teaching Church, which history attests is the Catholic Church.

All Christians agree that Jesus Christ is the ultimate authority. During his earthly ministry, He was the Final Authority. His authority superseded the Old Testament, human reason, Jewish Tradition, and the power of the state.

But after His ascension, He did not leave us without direction. Before He ascended, He made provisions for a continuing doctrinal authority.

Jesus commissioned his apostles to teach with authority:

Jesus told his disciples, “All power in heaven and on earth has been given to me. Go, therefore, and make disciples of all nations . . . teaching them to observe all that I have commanded you. And behold, I am with you always, until the end of the age.” (Matt. 28:18-20)

Jesus sent his apostles to teach, and promised to remain with them. Many passages of Scripture show that Christ’s authority accompanied their teaching:

- “As the Father has sent me, so I send you.” (John 20:21)

- “Whoever listens to you listens to me. Whoever rejects you rejects me. And whoever rejects me rejects the one who sent me.” (Luke 10:16)

- “Whatever you bind on earth shall be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.” (Matt. 16:18; Matt. 18:18)

These texts answer the question: Christ did give us a rule of faith before His ascension. He gave us the teaching of the apostles.

It is important to note that Christ never mentions the *writings* of the apostles.

He gave them no command to write, and never restricted their authority to the written word. His authority attached to **their persons and their teaching**.

Cont.

1/3

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
2/3

*The Apostles Appointed Successors to Teach with Authority*

Protestants usually admit that the apostles taught with authority. They deny that the apostles transmitted this authority to their successors. However, Scripture and history refute them.

Scripture:

- “They appointed presbyters for them in each church.” (Acts 14:23)

- [Paul to Titus] “For this reason I left you in Crete so that you might . . . appoint presbyters in every town, as I directed you.” (Titus 1:5)

- [Paul to Timothy] “And what you heard from me through many witnesses entrust to faithful people who will have the ability to teach others as well.” (2 Timothy 2:2)

- “For a bishop as God’s steward must . . . be able both to exhort with sound doctrine and to refute opponents.” (Titus 1:7-9)

These texts show clearly that the apostles appointed the bishops and priests (presbyters) who took over the leadership of the infant church. They also show that leaders were 1) stewards of the Gospel, 2) given authority to teach and refute false doctrine, 3) ordered to entrust this charge to others.

Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
3/3

History:

The earliest sources outside the New Testament attest the belief that the apostles appointed successors who continued to teach with authority.

- The First Epistle of Clement, c. 42 (written sometime between A.D. 70-96): “Christ therefore was sent forth by God and the apostles by Christ . . . [T]hey [the apostles] appointed the first fruits [of their labours], having first proved them by the Spirit, to be bishops and deacons of those who should afterwards believe.”

- St. Ignatius to the Ephesians, (between A.D. 98-117): “For we ought to receive every one whom the Master of the house sends to be over His household, as we would do Him that sent him. It is manifest, therefore, that we should look upon the bishop even as we would upon the Lord Himself.”

Conclusion

The heart of the Protestant apologetic for sola scriptura is not the teaching of Christ, but the alleged failure of the Church’s magisterial authority. Consider Luther’s famous argument at Leipzig: Councils can err; therefore Scripture is the final authority. The Protestant position infers canonical authority from inspiration. But this is not a valid inference. God can inspire a text without intending that text to serve as a final authority for all matters doctrinal.

I am well aware that Protestants will dispute the Catholic understanding of the texts I have cited. This is not threatening, and we should have a lively discussion about what they mean. What Protestants must concede, however, is that Catholics attempt to ground their doctrine of authority on the teaching of Christ and the apostles. They do not resort to tenuous logical inferences. Can Protestant apologists do the same?

Source: https://www.calledtocommunion.com/2011/03/sola-scriptura-vs-the-magisterium-what-did-jesus-teach/

>The scriptural citations establish the duties of presbyters

The scriptural citations establish where Jesus Christ established His authority -- in the apostles. And they establish that the apostles passed on that authorities to the bishops whom they appointed.

The role of apostolic succession in preserving true doctrine is stated by Paul: To make sure that the apostles’ teachings would be passed down after the deaths of the apostles, Paul told Timothy:
>“[W]hat you have heard from me before many witnesses entrust to faithful men who will be able to teach others also” (2 Tim. 2:2).

In this passage Paul refers to the first three generations of apostolic succession—his own generation, Timothy’s generation, and the generation Timothy will teach.

>You need to demonstrate that the actual apostolic authority passes down to later clergy

The above text demonstrates it, along with the other, related texts I quoted above.

By the end of the second century, apostolic succession was understood as the sure indicator of orthodoxy. St. Irenaeus of Lions, writing against the Gnostics around the year 180:
>Since, however, it would be very tedious, in such a volume as this, to reckon up the successions of all the Churches, we do put to confusion all those who, in whatever manner, whether by an evil self-pleasing, by vainglory, or by blindness and perverse opinion, assemble in unauthorized meetings; [we do this, I say,] by indicating that tradition derived from the apostles, of the very great, the very ancient, and universally known Church founded and organized at Rome by the two most glorious apostles, Peter and Paul; as also [by pointing out] the faith preached to men, which comes down to our time by means of the successions of the bishops.
>For it is a matter of necessity that every Church should agree with this Church, on account of its preeminent authority.
--St. Irenaeus, Against Heresies 3.3.2, 180 AD

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14482983
>Honoring something is venerating it.

I don't think that's right.

I think the language of Nicaea II you have quoted involves a distinction between "honoring" and "saluting" an image, on the one hand, and "venerating" an image on the other.

With the relevance of this being that with that distinction in place, it is reasonably clear that the language of Nicaea does not speak of venerating the image *as image*, but rather ONLY "honoring" or "saluting" the image as image.

The long and short of it is this: "he who reveres the image reveres in it the subject represented."

But as I read Nicaea, it does not impose the requirement of venerating or revering an image (in the sense of the above quote), but does require at least "honoring" or "saluting" those images, which is a different thing.

The distinction you're making is meaningless. Catholicism and Orthodoxy distinguish between latria (worship) and dulia (veneration). Latria is the honor due to God alone, and dulia is honor which is less than that due to God alone. If you are saying that honor is given to the image, you're saying it is beign given dulia, which is veneration.
>The long and short of it is this: "he who reveres the image reveres in it the subject represented."
Nicaea II states "the honour which is paid to the image passes on to that which the image represents", which is a concept they take out of context from Basil. You are trying to get around this for some reason, but that is the basic formula utilized by iconodule theology. You say you don't know much about this so I think you should go study it.
>it does not impose the requirement of venerating or revering an image
It quite clearly does:

>>... we salute the honourable images! Those who do not so hold, let them be anathema. Those who do not thus think, let them be driven far away from the Church. ... We salute the venerable images. We place under anathema those who do not do this. ... Anathema to those who do not salute the holy and venerable images.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14483101
>The distinction you're making is meaningless.

I don't think so, for the reasons stated.

>You are trying to get around this for some reason
Actually, I'm not. I just quoted the one part because it was to my point, but I have no objection to including the other part also:

"For the honour which is paid to the image passes on to that which the image represents, and he who reveres the image reveres in it the subject represented."
Source: https://history.hanover.edu/courses/excerpts/211icon3.html

Now you claim my distinction is meaningless, but I consistently see that distinction being drawn in the language of Nicaea, including the above quote.

>>it does not impose the requirement of venerating or revering an image
>It quite clearly does:
>... we salute the honourable images! Those who do not so hold, let them be anathema.

No, it quite clearly requires "saluting" or "honoring" veneration-worthy images, but it does not *require* *venerating* those images.

Your point would be made IF the language of Nicaea included the words in brackets:
>... we [venerate] the honourable images! Those who do not so hold, let them be anathema.
>... We [venerate] the venerable images. We place under anathema those who do not do this.

But Nicaea does *not* do this! And thus it does not impose the requirement of venerating images, but merely of honoring them.

>"For the honour which is paid to the image passes on to that which the image represents, and he who reveres the image reveres in it the subject represented."

Now, consider this quote. If "honour" means the same thing as "revere," then the statement is duplicative, with the second part of the sentence simply repeating what is said in the first part of the sentence with a different but synonymous word, which suggests poor syntax of a kind that is not consistent with a formal document, that is, the polished, finished statement of an ecumenical council.

A more reasonable interpretation is that two *different* things are being said in the sentence, in the first part wrt "honouring" an image, and in the second part wrt "revering" an image.

Reading through these "battles" it's pretty much always hundreds of Chinese ships and tens of thousands of Chinese soldiers versus like... 6 European ships at most, with most of the European "combatants" being sailors rather than soldiers. The "Dutch fleet" was actually a Dutch trading company, and the "Portuguese fleet" was actually a diplomatic envoy sent to establish a trading post at Guangzhou, and was not even armed with any heavy cannon because they weren't expecting to be ambushed by an army 50x their size when they arrived. Even then they lost only 2 of their 6 ships and less than 50 sailors before managing to escape. Ming China proclaimed this a great victory over the mostly unarmed traders of Portugal, hence dubbed "the barbarian fleet".

Even funnier is that pretty much all of these naval battles were situations where the Chinese attacked Europeans without warning then claimed victory after vanquishing an enemy with a fraction of their own number. Only Russia was different, because it was a case of China and Russia squabbling over control of a region that was on both their borders. Russia scouted it and established a fort, then China attacked the fort several times to force the Russian expedition to leave. I'll give the Chinese credit for this, they "only" outnumbered the Russians 3000 to 2000, a landmark in Chinese-western conflict, though it came at the cost of several hundred Chinese soldiers' lives since they did not outnumber the enemy 10-1 as normal.

>During the siege of Fort Zeelandia, the Chinese took many Dutch prisoners, among them the Dutch missionary Antonius Hambroek and his wife, and two of their daughters. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Several issues.

1: Human intelligence. East Slavic peoples in particular (Belarusians, Russians and Ukrainians) are significantly less intelligent than Germanic peoples. When you have a very broad front line with difficulty communicating, a lot of outcomes hinge on the intelligence of NCOs and men in the moment. One artilleryman's faulty calculation can allow for an enemy breakthrough; one map reading failure can cause an entire column of armored vehicles to stop in its tracks (as we saw last year). In this sense, the Germans had a major advantage over the Russians.

2: Rigidity of command. The Red Army in World War II, much like the Russian army in Ukraine today, suffered from a problem of oscillation: their officer corps went back and forth between being utterly disorganized and being overly rigid. Sometimes all order broke down; sometimes officers stayed put against their own judgment because to disobey even an irrational order was to invite charges of desertion. The Germans, on the other hand, had an excellent officer corps, who were allowed through the Auftragstaktik system to accomplish known objectives in their own way, without having to constantly await orders.

3: Morale. German officers, while undeniably brutal and hierarchical, had a much higher level of support among their men. Many of their men also felt that they fought for a good and glorious cause. Soviet soldiers, on the other hand, had awful morale for the most part. They spent the first year of the war retreating in panic, and the remaining three years being methodically inserted into a meat grinder on the way to Berlin. Add to this the poor quality of their command structure, the lower level of human intelligence and the heavy political weight that leaned on them constantly (with roaming NKVD detachments constantly looking for an excuse to frame people to make quotas), and you have a recipe for disaster.

The uranium and lead found in zircon is not a closed system, it's an open system, it is subject to other forces that can change the data you're analyzing. There are geological forces that can affect the amount of uranium and lead in zircon, that's a fact. Zircon is not invincible to all things that can change the amounts of uranium and lead in it, it's not a perfect time capsule, it's an open system. You're assuming that nothing has ever affected the amounts of uranium or lead in that open system. Uranium lead dating of zircon is not a reliable method of dating the age of the earth.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14481155
No, because there was no Greco-Roman religion.

The people of pre-Christian Rome were not religious as we understand the concept of religion. Their culture had no unified holy scripture or system of beliefs shared across all people. What we think of as the Greco-Roman religion was fabricated during the 18th and 19th centuries as an over-simplification by historians viewing the practices of the past through the lens of Christian worldview.

To the people who lived in Greece and Rome, there were a multitude of devotional cults of individual gods and goddesses with semi-overlapping mythos. Most people were aware of the shared narrative of the mythos, but were not initiated in the deeper beliefs of any particular cult in the manner of a Christian reading the Bible. To the extent that an ordinary person engaged with the gods, they did so in a way that was more like a subject petitioning a king, mixed with superstition. Prayer and sacrifice were not a matter of proving faith, but rather of purchasing favor.

There's no way you could get someone who grew up Christian to properly conduct himself like an ancient Greek with respect to religious matters. Even if you get him to leave Christ behind, he's just going to view Zeus and Athena and the rest like dozens of Christs, not like pagans viewed their gods.

Yeah, I'm sure the angry one here. Meanwhile, you clearly have a personal investment to claim I hate Spain. Meanwhile, you're not even qualified to talk about the country you love oh, so much and live in a fictional world where Belgium is part of present day France. I suppose such a world is also one where your delusional interpretation of history is somehow valid.

Actually historians like Henry Kamen, who has written extensively on Spain - with his entire bibliography of works essentially being dedicated to the country", has referred to the War of Devolution as a conflict which "confirmed the decay of Spain's military power (Spain: A Society of Conflict, pg. 282)."

The rapid advance of French armies into the Spanish Netherlands and France-Comte detail the scale of French success. John A. Lynn, another historian who has published multiple works on France in addition to military history in general, also described the War of Devolution as a being a "brief conflict [which was] essentially a walkover by mighty France against Feeble Spain. It saw some skirmishes but no great field battle, instead it was a war of seizures and sieges. Bergues, Ath, Charleroi, Tournai, Douai, Oudenarde, and Alost fell immedietaly or after only very brief sieges. (The Wars of Louis XIV, pg. 106-108)." The Triple Alliance was the only thing that apparently preempted the conquest of the entire Spanish Netherlands, with "Turenne [opposing] the peace, since he believed he could have conquered the Spanish Netherlands that year (pg. 109)."

France-Comte was also conquered with the leading general having met "no substantial resistance pg. 108)." We also see in the later Franco-Dutch War, which Spain joined as part of a large coalition, that "[France-Comte] was secured in a campaign of only six weeks (pg. 124)" with France's forces spread relatively thin given their commitments and the size of the coalition descending upon them.

In the ethnically diverse court entourage, jewelry was influenced by far away Iran. The gold filigree ornaments with turquoise-colored insets found in the tomb of an official called Shi Gang are derived from Iranian models. Shi Gang’s father was Chinese but his mother came from the north Asian Jurchen people. An epitaph in the tomb further reveals that his wife belonged to the Turkic Kerait community. The hairpin, the earring and the two rings recovered from the funerary chamber were hers.
Shi Gang’s father had had four spouses. One was Chinese, two were Jurchen and one was Korean. Another large tomb in the Shi family burial ground yielded a Korean celadon porcelain jar of the 13th century.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Although the Martinsville Seven are not well-remembered today, their case was an eventual catalyst for death penalty reform in the US. The case involved a septet of black men, ranging in ages from 20 to 38, who were executed by the state of Virginia in what has been described as "a legal lynching."

The case began on January 8, 1949 when Ruby Floyd, a white woman and practicing Jehovah's Witness in her early 30s, was gang-raped in the black section of Martinsville where she had gone to collect money for clothing she'd sold. The seven men, Frank Hairston, Francis Grayson, Booker Millner, James Hairson, Howard Hairston, Joe Hampton, and John Taylor, were quickly convicted and found guilty by an all-white jury. A month before their executions, the Supreme Court declined to hear the case. The lawyers for the Martinsville Seven, although ultimately unsuccessful, had appealed based on the novel claim of equal protection rather than due process (the Virginia state supreme court argued that "equal protection in this case means the state will have to execute one white person for each Negro executed.")

The case seemed open-and-shut as far as Virginia was concerned. The accused had confessed and at least one witness to the rape said they were drunk when they decided to attack Mrs. Floyd. Eric Rise, author of "The Martinsville Seven: Race, Rape, and Capital Punishment", noted in a scholarly article that the trial of the Marysville Seven had been conducted properly and in accordance with Virginia legal procedures, and at no point during the trial was their race emphasized or brought up. Nonetheless, Miranda Rights didn't yet exist in 1949 and police interrogation of the seven suspects was not conducted in the manner it would be today.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Ruby Floyd had testified at the trials. Four of the defendants took the witness stand themselves. Two claimed they had had sex with Mrs. Floyd, but it had been consensual, one denied everything, and a fourth said he was very drunk that day and couldn't remember anything.

Governor John Battle was flooded with letters from as far away as Europe asking for mercy for the Martinsville Seven while the NAACP staged a protest outside the White House on February 1, 1951 calling on President Truman to stop the executions. All four were executed in the electric chair in the state pen within the following 72 hours.

In 1972, the Supreme Court ordered capital punishment suspended nationwide until states could rewrite their death penalty guidelines. This requirement having been largely satisfied, they re-allowed its use four years later. One of the Supreme Court's demands included the abolition of capital punishment for any offense short of first degree murder. Rape had previously been a capital crime in a number of states, and the Court's primary objection to this was the idea that such executions were racially motivated. Since the electric chair replacing hangings as the standard form of execution in Virginia back in 1908, there had been 45 executions for rape. Not one of them was white.

Virginia executed three more men for rape, all black. The first was Albert Jackson, who raped and brutally beat a 40 year old woman in Charlottesville on May 3, 1951. He was executed August 25, 1952. Lloyd Doby raped a 48 year old office worker in Courtland on February 9, 1955. He was executed April 18, 1958. Linwood Burch raped a 48 year old woman in Newport News during a robbery and home invasion on September 20, 1958. He was executed February 17, 1961. All three men had prior rap sheets and convictions.

Governor Ralph Northam granted a posthumous pardon to the Martinsville Seven in 2021, seven decades after their untimely end. "These men were executed because they were black, and that’s not right. Their punishment did not fit the crime. They should not have been executed," the governor remarked.

James Walter Grayson is the son of Francis DeSales Grayson, who was one of the seven. He sobbed loudly when Northam told the family members he would grant the pardons after meeting with them Tuesday. "Thank you, Jesus. Thank you, Lord," he said, as he wept while being embraced by two other descendants of the men.

Grayson said he was 4 years old when his father was executed.

"It means so much to me," he said of the pardon.

"I remember the very day the police came to the door. He kissed us and they took him away,” he told The Associated Press in an interview after the announcement.

Kazan's family originates from Cappadocia, the interior of Anatolia, Cappadocian Greeks are the only Greeks where the whole 'Hellenized Anatolian' bullshit is actually true for the most part.
On a sidenote, Cappadocia was the first part of the Greek world to come under Turkish control, dating back to the Seljuks. However, this meant that Muslim and Christian communities rarely intermingled, as when one converted to Islam, they would be deemed a Turk and thereby become separate from the Cappadocian Greeks. Conversely, you had a subgroup called the Karamanlides, a Turkish-speaking community of Greek Orthodox Christians.
Elia Kazan, was a Cappadocian Greek though. His last name translates to son of a boiler/cauldron maker, typically for ouzo or raki.

posts.com:
Art is an expression of the human creative spirit.
So from the perspective of a human, AI "art" is by definition garbage.
Just its existence poses a problem since it means having to sift through a sea of AI garbage to actually find art, and it's fully endorsed by society then it will inevitably lower the amount of people who actually know how to draw.
Once the stream of human-made real art dwindles, the AI will hit a creative wall since it's only as good as it is now thanks to the mountains of existing real art that was taken and fed to it by the programmers. Enjoy the creative sterility and infinite regurgitation that is to come.
And if (or when) the day comes that the AI gets good enough to be truly creative, I think there will be bigger problems on hand than the issue of image creation.

One point that interests me is how as time goes on the publishing date will become a key factor in the value of art, as it will be the most reliable metric of determining whether or not something was AI-made. Anything pre-2022 will be trustworthy, and anything post-2022 will be subject to scrutiny. Will there be people forging records to try to pass off AI output as legitimate human art?

>Yishiha (Chinese: 亦失哈; Wade–Giles: Ishiha/I-shih-ha; also Išiqa or Isiha[1] Jurchen: Yishiha.svg i ʃï xa[2]) (fl. 1409–1451) was a Jurchen eunuch in the service of the Ming dynasty emperors who carried out several expeditions down the Songhua and Amur Rivers during the period of Ming rule of Manchuria,[1][3] and is credited with the construction of the only two Ming dynasty Buddhist temples ever built on the territory of present-day Russia.[4]

>Nguyễn An (Sino-Vietnamese 阮安; died 1453), known in Chinese as Ruan An (pinyin)[1] or Juan An[2] (Wade-Giles), was a Ming dynasty eunuch, architect, and hydraulics specialist between the first and fifth decades of the 15th century. Born in Vietnam, he was taken as tribute from Vietnam to China and later became a eunuch and architect in service to the Chinese emperors. He, along with numerous architects, such as master designers and planners Cai Xin (蔡信), Chen Gui (陳珪), and Wu Zhong (吳中), master carpenter Kuai Xiang (蒯祥), and master mason Lu Xiang (陸祥), was an important builder[3] of the Forbidden City in Beijing.[4]

>Pat did not have an easy upbringing; as Dick was to learn later, her birthname wasn't even Pat, it was Thelma. She was ten months older than him, born in the little California farming community of Artesia, one of four children of William and Kate Ryan, two girls and three boys. William was a hot-tempered Irish prospector and Kate a German immigrant who moved to California from North Dakota after her first husband was killed in a drowning accident and remarried (two of Pat's siblings were halfs from Kate's first marriage). The Ryans eked out a living from the soil and were much closer to real poverty than the Nixons over in Whittier experienced. They had no plumbing or electricity for much of her childhood; all the children had to perform farm chores as soon as they were old enough, although a girl was a lot more limited in what she could do.

>When Thelma was a small child, Will would sometimes bring her with him on a hay wagon into town on business. One time when she was about 7, he joked to a friend that he ought to sell his daughter and get some money for her. "I was absolutely terrified and started crying because I thought he really meant it," she recalled of the incident.

>Thelma and her half-sister Neva were tomboys who would sneak behind the barn to smoke cigarettes (Pat took up what would be a lifelong habit when she was 10 years old) and wore jeans instead of skirts, which scandalized the old ladies in town. She had few possessions; just one doll and had to share a room with her siblings for much of her childhood.

>After high school, Thelma enrolled in Fullerton Junior College, spent a semester there, and then got an offer she couldn't refuse when she was invited to chauffeur a wealthy elderly couple across the country to NYC where her aunt lived. >Settling into NYC she worked in the TB ward of a Catholic hospital where her aunt was a nun and dutifully and fearlessly worked long shifts at the risk of catching the disease herself. It was not long after high school that she decided to start calling herself "Patricia" as she had never liked her birth name, and because her birthday fell on March 17, St. Patrick's Day. By 1934, Pat had saved a decent enough nest egg to head back to California, where she enrolled in college and paid tuition with assorted jobs including working as a clerk in the fashionable LA department store Bullocks. Because of her good looks, she was sometimes employed as a cosmetics demonstrator, and a movie extra for $6.50 a day--almost $140 in 2022 dollars. Pat had a single speaking line in the MGM film "Becky Sharp", although it didn't make it into the final edit of the movie.

>>14481689
>where's the experience?
The actions of the brain.

The problem is that you're comparing the brain to a computer. In a computer a series of electrons being in certain states "is" the data. You can, theoretically, take these electrons, in some configuration, and remove them from the computer (this obviously doesn't work, but it's still theoretically possible). That's not the case with the brain, as it's constantly in motion. If you must make a comparison of brains and computers, the brain is a bunch of peripherals plugged into a motherboard with no CPU or hard drive, just huge amounts of RAM; because the same RAM that is used for, say, visual processing, is ALSO used for memory (there's no hard drive, remember), the memories are never "stored" anywhere, but are rather constantly being moved around. A simple empirical demonstration of this is why your memories change, such as viewing certain events in your head from a ghostly third-person camera, or from the point of view of someone else present. So, yes, this does mean that a mind is only doing anything over time: a mind frozen in time doesn't do any thinking, and is basically dead.

So, yes, correct, materialists argue that you cannot hold a memory in your hand, or experience, or any mental phenomena, because these things aren't material, they're processes. Materialists (who I suppose should be rebranded to something like "brains cause minds"-ists or something) aren't required to believe that everything is matter, they aren't monists after all (it would be absurd to argue that everything is matter given that spacetime is very real and isn't matter).

Dualists, however, do actually have to hold that memories are discrete, physical things, made out of matter, it's just a different kind of matter than, say, hands are made out of. Dualists ARE required to believe that memories are made out of mind-atoms, or some kind of equivalent.

>>14482436
>Why do modern Christians think all magic is bad when ancient Christians and Jews used to learn about and use it all the time?

This was more or less always a belief held by the vague body of the Continental European Church. It was kind of the idea that there was only two sources of magic: God given Miracles, Devil sourced Sorcerey & Witchcraft. That's it. So with that in mind the Church had an obviousy monopoly on what one would consider "Good/White Magic" and anyone doing magic outside of the Church was obviously evil (and competition) and in bed with Satan.
Better you die from a disease God premediated you to have in the first place than accept help from Satan.

In places isolated from Rome and the central body of Christianity it was more difficult to introduce, enforce, and maintain this idea so opinions about this were more nuanced in the British Isles, Scandenavia, parts of Eastern European. People would assimilate their Pagan Anglo-Saxan and Nordic beliefs into the body of Christianity to fill in the cosmological gaps. Magic could now come from God (Miracles), as an inherent property of *Nature (White or Benign Magic), and of course Satan (Black Magic). ASTROLOGY & Alchemy didn't get introduced as a school of magic until maybe the 1500-1600's when the UK finally started getting books and equipment from Egypt, the Middle-East, Rome, and that was also given some benefit of the doubt from being classified as a *Natural Sorcerery.

*Nature, the argument concerning "Natural Magic" was the Creationist concept that God didn't create anything that wasn't of use to Humans. Combine this with the idea that Humans were largely expected to help themselves; naturally lead to the idea that people aut' not bother God with every trivial little thing and seek out lesser supernatural solutions to everyday problems.

there's some weird shit going on in Jacob's story. One example:

>God said to Jacob, “Arise, go up to Bethel, and settle there. Make an altar there to the God who appeared to you when you fled from your brother Esau.” 2 So Jacob said to his household and to all who were with him, “Put away the foreign gods that are among you, and purify yourselves, and change your clothes; 3 then come, let us go up to Bethel, that I may make an altar there to the God who answered me in the day of my distress and has been with me wherever I have gone.” 4 So they gave to Jacob all the foreign gods that they had and the rings that were in their ears, and Jacob hid them under the oak that was near Shechem.

Genesis 35

First of all, it's assumed almost like it was normal that his family had foreign gods among them. Instead of going all idol-smashy Jacob appears to treat the idols with respect, and "hid" them under the oak near Shechem.

It appears to me that Jacob was not a Yahweh-one-ist. He does however worship Yahweh first among the gods and does not bring other gods into Yahweh's holy place, just as you would purify yourself before entering the Holy of Holies. This last part is my interpretation, but scholars have taken note that Jacob here has a much more relaxed attitude toward foreign gods/idols than you would find in the Exodus story.

posts.com: Would the Taiping Heavenly kingdom have worked?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As a functioning government? Sure. After taking Nanjing they had a few good years where they basically acted as a functioning state: making laws, collecting taxes, public works, etc. They even minted their own currency called the Shengbao ("Holy Treasure" lol). The Taiping's prime minister Hong Rengan was a reformist visionary who wanted closer and better ties to the west, including industrialization. I think that if he had the opportunity to actually implement his plans without being in a life or death struggle with the Qing, then the Kingdom may have been better set-up towards modernization than the stagnant Qing.

I read a book on the Taiping that even suggests that moving from a basically nomadic and dynamic revolution into a sedentary kingdom so early on may have taken out some of the momentum that was making the Qing shit bricks during the beginning.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
One fall afternoon in 1954, Ann Hodges, a 34 year old housewife, was napping on her couch in her Sylacuga, Alabama home when a meteorite crashed through the roof and struck her side, leaving a grapefruit-sized bruise. During an era of Cold War tensions, Air Force officials arrived to take possession of the object to confirm it was natural and not man-made. The eight pound space rock was indeed natural. Hodges's husband insisted it landed in their home and thus belonged to them by default, and the Air Force could not simply take it without their permission. The latter said they would return it after weighing and chemically analyzing it. However, the Hodges' landlord insisted the meteorite belonged to her.

The case was settled out of court as the Hodges paid their landlord $500 ($5020 in 2020 dollars) to keep the meteorite. However, not knowing what else to do with it and unable to sell it, they eventually donated it to the Alabama Museum of Natural History.

Ann Hodges died in 1972, aged only 52, of kidney failure. She remains the only human known to have been struck by a meteorite.
